Front: Define: odium (oh-dee-um)
Back: n. repugnance, hatred n. strong dislike The popular odium of attorneys is often unmerited. Root: odi (from Latin odium, meaning “hatred”)

Front: Define: officious (uh-fish-us)
Back: adj. prone to giving unwanted advice I make a habit of giving honest opinions, but I try to avoid being officious with my friends. Prefix: ob- (from Latin, meaning “toward” or “against”); Root: facere (from Latin, meaning “to do” or “to make”); Suffix: -ious (forming adjectives, meaning “full of” or “having the qualities of”)

Front: Define: opaque (owe-peyk)
Back: adj. blocking all light adj. hard to understand The windows became so dirty they were almost opaque. Root: opaqu (from Latin opacus, meaning “shady” or “dark”)

Front: Define: opportune (opp-er-tune)
Back: adj. happening under fitting circumstances, or at an appropriate or favorable time The students waited for an opportune moment to surprise their teacher with the bouquet of flowers they had prepared. Prefix: ob- (from Latin, meaning “toward” or “against”); Root: port (from Latin portus, meaning “harbor” or “port”)

Front: Define: superfluous (suh-per-flu-us)
Back: adj. more than necessary; unnecessary The student's essay was full of superfluous phrases that needed to be deleted. Prefix: super- (from Latin, meaning “above” or “beyond”); Root: flu (from Latin fluere, meaning “to flow”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “full of”)

Front: Define: supersede (sue-per-seed)
Back: v. to substitute; to take precedence over It had been my understanding that the new tax code supersedes the old one, but actually both are in vigor simultaneously. Prefix: super- (from Latin, meaning “above” or “beyond”); Root: sed (from Latin sedere, meaning “to sit”)

Front: Define: supplant (suh-plant)
Back: v. to replace The higher-ups tried to supplant rebellious teachers with conformists. Prefix: sub- (altered to sup- before certain consonants, meaning “under” or “below”); Root: plant (from Latin plantare, meaning “to plant”)

Front: Define: supplicate (sup-lih-kate)
Back: v. to humbly ask The churchgoers then bowed their heads and supplicated God to answer their prayers. Prefix: sub- (altered to sup- before certain consonants, meaning “under” or “below”); Root: plic (from Latin plicare, meaning “to fold”)

Front: Define: surmount (ser-mount)
Back: v. to overcome v. to rise above Through sheer determination, he was able to surmount his disadvantages and win the contest outright. Prefix: sur- (from Old French, meaning “over” or “above”); Root: mount (from Latin montare, meaning “to climb”)

Front: Define: surreptitious (ser-up-tish-us)
Back: adj. secretive Since they were not allowed to speak, the couple exchanged surreptitious glances from across the room. Prefix: sub- (altered to sur- before certain consonants, meaning “under” or “secretly”); Root: rapt (from Latin rapere, meaning “to seize”); Suffix: -ious (forming adjectives, meaning “full of”)

Front: Define: symbiotic (sim-bee-ott-ik)
Back: adj. related to a relationship between two or more organisms living together The whale and the small fish that cling to its body have a symbiotic relationship. Prefix: sym- (from Greek syn, meaning “together”); Root: bio (from Greek bios, meaning “life”); Suffix: -ic (forming adjectives, meaning “pertaining to”)

Front: Define: synapse (sin-apse)
Back: n. the small gap between the cells of nerves Neurotransmitters travel across the synapse between brain cells. Prefix: syn- (from Greek, meaning “together”); Root: apse (from Greek haptein, meaning “to fasten”)

Front: Define: synchronous (sing-kruh-nuss)
Back: adj. operating at the same time or at the same rate The film was notable for its synchronous premiere in 11 capital cities around the globe. Prefix: syn- (from Greek, meaning “together”); Root: chron (from Greek chronos, meaning “time”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “full of”)

Front: Define: tacit (tass-it)
Back: adj. implied or unspoken There was a tacit agreement between the two companies that neither would expand into the other's city. Root: tac (from Latin tacitus, meaning “silent”)

Front: Define: taciturn (tass-ih-turn)
Back: adj. tending to be silent; quiet Some of the students were quite taciturn and had to be asked to participate more. Root: tac (from Latin tacitus, meaning “silent”); Suffix: -urn (forming adjectives, indicating a tendency)

Front: Define: exacerbate (ig-zass-er-bate)
Back: v. to make worse The children's screaming exacerbated their father's headache. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “thoroughly”); Root: acerb (from Latin acerbus, meaning “bitter” or “harsh”)

Front: Define: exact (ig-zact)
Back: v. to forcibly obtain The detectives finally exacted the truth from the witness. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “thoroughly”); Root: act (from Latin agere, meaning “to do” or “to drive”)

Front: Define: exculpate (ek-skull-pate)
Back: v. to free from blame The political prisoner was fully exculpated only when the dictatorship was overthrown and an independent truth commission established. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “from”); Root: culp (from Latin culpa, meaning “fault” or “blame”)

Front: Define: exhort (ig-zort)
Back: v. to urge by strong appeal Taking the loudspeaker in her hand, the policewoman exhorted the kidnapper to release his hostage. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “thoroughly”); Root: hort (from Latin hortari, meaning “to encourage” or “to urge”)

Front: Define: exigent (ek-suh-djunt)
Back: adj. requiring immediate attention; pressing, demanding The show's run was cut short by an exigent lack of funds. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out” or “thoroughly”); Root: ig (from Latin agere, meaning “to drive” or “to act”); Suffix: -ent (forming adjectives, meaning “performing an action”)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. blame n. strong dislike Hint: starts with “o”
Back: odium synonyms: shame, dishonor; disgust, detestation, contempt, aversion, revulsion He faced odium from his peers after the project failed due to his oversight. The odium directed at the politician was palpable after the controversial decision.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ nature made her unpopular at social gatherings, as she constantly offered unsolicited tips. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “meddlesome in offering unwanted help”.
Back: officious officious (uh-fish-us) adj. prone to giving unwanted advice

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. blocking all light adj. hard to understand Hint: starts with “o”
Back: opaque synonyms: blurred, darkened, lusterless; baffling, cryptic, clouded, unclear, ambiguous The opaque curtains kept the room completely dark even during midday. His explanation was so opaque that no one in the class could follow his logic.

Front: Fill in the blank: The job offer came at an ________ moment, just as she was considering a career change. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “timely or well-chosen”.
Back: opportune opportune (opp-er-tune) adj. happening under fitting circumstances

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. more than necessary; unnecessary Hint: starts with “s”
Back: superfluous synonyms: extra, excessive, overdone, redundant, unnecessary, surplus Her apology seemed superfluous, as the issue had already been resolved.

Front: Fill in the blank: The new law will ________ the outdated regulations next year. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “to replace or take the place of”.
Back: supersede supersede (sue-per-seed) v. to substitute; to take precedence over

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to replace Hint: starts with “s”
Back: supplant synonyms: substitute, usurp, replace, displace As technology evolves, new devices continually supplant older models in the market.

Front: Fill in the blank: The villagers ________ for rain during the prolonged drought. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “to beg or pray earnestly”.
Back: supplicated supplicate (sup-lih-kate) v. to humbly ask

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to overcome v. to rise above Hint: starts with “s”
Back: surmount synonyms: vanquish, transcend, overcome, rise above, conquer She managed to surmount all obstacles and graduate at the top of her class. The athlete's determination allowed him to surmount his previous records.

Front: Fill in the blank: Their ________ meeting was held late at night to avoid detection. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “done secretly or stealthily”.
Back: surreptitious surreptitious (ser-up-tish-us) adj. secretive

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. related to a relationship between two or more organisms living together Hint: starts with “s”
Back: symbiotic synonyms: coactive, harmonious, joining, interdependent, collaborative, mutual The symbiotic relationship between the bees and flowers benefits both species.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ is crucial for transmitting signals between neurons in the brain. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “a junction between nerve cells”.
Back: synapse synapse (sin-apse) n. the small gap between the cells of nerves

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. operating at the same time or at the same rate Hint: starts with “s”
Back: synchronous synonyms: concurrent, simultaneous, coordinated, aligned, parallel The dancers moved in synchronous harmony, perfectly in sync with the music.

Front: Fill in the blank: There was a ________ understanding between them, even though no words were exchanged. Hint: Starts with “t” and means “understood without being stated”.
Back: tacit tacit (tass-it) adj. implied or unspoken

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. tending to be silent; quiet Hint: starts with “t”
Back: taciturn synonyms: aloof, silent, mum, reserved, reticent, quiet He remained taciturn throughout the meeting, preferring to listen rather than speak.

Front: Fill in the blank: His careless remarks only ________ the tense situation. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “made worse or more severe”.
Back: exacerbated exacerbate (ig-zass-er-bate) v. to make worse

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to forcibly obtain Hint: starts with “e”
Back: exact synonyms: claim, take, demand, require, impose The conqueror exacted heavy taxes from the subdued population.

Front: Fill in the blank: New evidence helped to ________ the accused of all charges. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to clear from blame”.
Back: exculpate exculpate (ek-skull-pate) v. to free from blame

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to urge by strong appeal Hint: starts with “e”
Back: exhort synonyms: warn, beseech, encourage, urge, implore The coach exhorted his team to give their best performance during the final match.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ nature of the patient's condition required immediate medical intervention. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “urgent or requiring immediate action”.
Back: exigent exigent (ek-suh-djunt) adj. requiring immediate attention; pressing, demanding

Front: Define: exonerate (ig-zawn-ih-rate)
Back: v. to clear of blame, guilt, or burden Though the defendant had clearly done something wrong, the court had no choice but to exonerate her on the present charges. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of” or “from”); Root: oner (from Latin onus, meaning “burden”)

Front: Define: expedient (ek-spee-dee-unt)
Back: adj. beneficial for one's goal n. a hastily prepared solution to a sudden problem The politician tended to bring up his humble origins when it was politically expedient. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of” or “from”); Root: ped (from Latin pes, meaning “foot”)

Front: Define: expedite (ek-spuh-dahyt)
Back: v. to speed up For an extra fee, the post office can expedite your package's delivery. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of” or “from”); Root: ped (from Latin pes, meaning “foot”)

Front: Define: expiate (ek-spee-ate)
Back: v. to atone for After destroying his friend's car, Jim hoped the fruit basket he sent would expiate his guilt. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of” or “from”); Root: pi (from Latin piare, meaning “to atone”)

Front: Define: extemporaneous (ik-stem-puh-ray-nee-us)
Back: adj. made up on the spot, ad-libbed To be a news anchor, she would have to improve her extemporaneous speaking skills. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of” or “from”); Root: tempor (from Latin tempus, meaning “time”)

Front: Define: extol (ik-stole)
Back: v. to praise Melinda was often heard extolling her daughter's many talents. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of” or “from”); Root: tol (from Latin tollere, meaning “to raise”)

Front: Define: extrapolate (ek-strap-ih-late)
Back: v. to make a guess based on facts Pete figured it was possible to extrapolate her personality from her Facebook profile. Prefix: extra- (from Latin, meaning “outside” or “beyond”); Root: pol (from Latin polire, meaning “to polish”)

Front: Define: extricate (ek-strih-kate)
Back: v. to disentangle, to break free from It was heartbreaking to watch the butterfly struggle in vain to extricate itself from the spider web. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning “out of” or “from”); Root: tric (from Latin tricae, meaning “perplexities”)

Front: Define: churl (churl)
Back: n. a rude person n. a cheap person I had been waiting in line for hours when some churl tried to cut in front of me. Root: ceorl (from Old English, meaning “man of low rank”)

Front: Define: circuitous (sir-cue-ih-tuss)
Back: adj. roundabout Because of the traffic accident, we had to take a circuitous route to the bank. Root: circuit (from Latin circuitus, meaning “a going around”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “full of”)

Front: Define circumscribe (sir-come-skrahyb)
Back: v. to draw or contain in a circle v. to limit or restrain I believe our government's actions are circumscribed by financial interests as well as moral imperatives. Prefix: circum- (from Latin, meaning “around”); Root: scribe (from Latin scribere, meaning “to write”)

Front: Define: circumspect (sir-come-spekt)
Back: adj. prudent; cautious Though her mother's boyfriend attempted to win affection with toys and treats, Elise remained circumspect around him. Prefix: circum- (from Latin, meaning “around”); Root: spect (from Latin specere, meaning “to look”)

Front: Define: circumvent (sir-kum-vent)
Back: v. to get around an obstacle She managed to circumvent security and approached her favorite actor backstage. Prefix: circum- (from Latin, meaning “around”); Root: vent (from Latin venire, meaning “to come”)

Front: Define: cleave (kleev)
Back: v. to cut off with force v. to be loyal to v. to develop an emotional bond with She vowed that even when tempted she would cleave to her principles. Root: cleofan (from Old English, meaning “to split” or “to adhere”)

Front: Define: cloister (cloy-stur)
Back: v. to isolate n. a place for religious isolation The boy's parents tended to cloister him from the harsher realities of the world. Root: cloist (from Latin claustrum, meaning “enclosure”)

Front: Define: coagulate (koh-ag-yuh-late)
Back: v. to clot or solidify The poorly-made syrup began to coagulate on the pancakes after a few minutes. Prefix: co- (from Latin, meaning “together”); Root: ag (from Latin agere, meaning “to drive”)

Front: Define: coalesce (koh-ih-less)
Back: v. to come together to form a single unit Our county's many poverty initiatives are too different to coalesce into an effective whole. Prefix: co- (from Latin, meaning “together”); Root: alesc (from Latin alescere, meaning “to grow”)

Front: Define: cogent (koh-djunt)
Back: adj. clear and convincing adj. relevant We won the debate because the other team was unable to mount a cogent counter argument. Root: cog (from Latin cogere, meaning “to drive together”)

Front: Define: cohere (koh-heer)
Back: v. to be logically connected to v. to stick to each other These short stories are quite charming when taken separately, but they will not cohere if published together as a collection. Prefix: co- (from Latin, meaning “together”); Root: here (from Latin haerere, meaning “to stick”)

Front: Define: intransigent (in-tran-suh-junt)
Back: adj. unwilling to compromise The government remained intransigent despite the people's protest. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning “not”); Root: transig (from Latin transigere, meaning “to come to an agreement”); Suffix: -ent (forming adjectives, meaning “performing or causing an action”)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to clear of blame or guilt Hint: starts with “e”
Back: exonerate synonyms: absolve, acquit, vindicate, clear, exculpate, discharge The new evidence exonerated the defendant, proving he had no involvement in the crime.

Front: Fill in the blank: Choosing the most ________ option, he decided to postpone the meeting to meet his deadline. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “convenient but possibly improper”.
Back: expedient expedient (ek-spee-dee-unt) adj. beneficial for one's goal n. a hastily prepared solution to a sudden problem

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to speed up Hint: starts with “e”
Back: expedite synonyms: accelerate, hasten, facilitate, quicken, speed up They hired more workers to expedite the construction process and finish ahead of schedule.

Front: Fill in the blank: He worked to ________ his guilt by volunteering at the local shelter. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to atone for or make amends”.
Back: expiate expiate (ek-spee-ate) v. to atone for wrongdoing

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. made up on the spot, ad-libbed Hint: starts with “e”
Back: extemporaneous synonyms: improvised, impromptu, unprepared, spontaneous, ad-libbed Her extemporaneous speech impressed the audience, despite being unplanned.

Front: Fill in the blank: The teacher ________ the student for her outstanding performance in the competition. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “praised highly”.
Back: extolled extol (ik-stole) v. to praise

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make a guess based on facts; to conjecture Hint: starts with “e”
Back: extrapolate synonyms: assume, hypothesize, infer, deduce, project Scientists used data from past experiments to extrapolate the likely outcome of the new test.

Front: Fill in the blank: It took hours to ________ the hiker from the thick underbrush. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to free from difficulty”.
Back: extricate extricate (ek-strih-kate) v. to disentangle, to break free from

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a rude person n. a cheap person Hint: starts with “c”
Back: churl synonyms: lout, oaf; miser, peasant, boor, clod, misanthrope The churl refused to hold the door open for the elderly woman. Known for his stinginess, the churl never tipped the waiter, no matter how good the service.

Front: Fill in the blank: Their journey took a ________ route through the countryside, avoiding the main highway. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “roundabout or indirect”.
Back: circuitous circuitous (sir-cue-ih-tuss) adj. roundabout

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to draw or contain in a circle v. to limit or restrain Hint: starts with “c”
Back: circumscribe synonyms: mark off, bound, confine, limit, restrict, delineate The artist circumscribed the design with a fine, precise border. The new rules circumscribe the amount of time employees can spend on personal tasks during work hours.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was ________ in his dealings, always thinking through the consequences before making a move. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “cautious and unwilling to take risks”.
Back: circumspect circumspect (sir-come-spekt) adj. prudent; cautious

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to get around an obstacle Hint: starts with “c”
Back: circumvent synonyms: avoid, bypass, dodge, evade, elude He found a clever way to circumvent the security system and access the restricted area.

Front: Fill in the blank: The lumberjack ________ the log in two with a single swing of his axe. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “split apart or clung to”.
Back: cleaved cleave (kleev) v. to split or sever (e.g., with force) v. to cling loyally or emotionally

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to isolate n. a place for religious isolation Hint: starts with “c”
Back: cloister synonyms: secluded, monastery, convent, retreat She chose to cloister herself in her room to focus on writing. The monks lived in a quiet cloister, far removed from the bustle of the city.

Front: Fill in the blank: The blood began to ________ shortly after the injury. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “to thicken or clot”.
Back: coagulate coagulate (koh-ag-yuh-late) v. to clot or solidify (for liquids)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to come together to form a single unit Hint: starts with “c”
Back: coalesce synonyms: adhere, cling, merge, unite, combine The small towns coalesced into a single city over time.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ argument persuaded everyone in the room. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “clear, logical, and convincing”.
Back: cogent cogent (koh-djunt) adj. clear and convincing adj. relevant

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to be logically connected to v. to stick to each other Hint: starts with “c”
Back: cohere synonyms: adhere, conform, stick, bond, unite The ideas in the paper cohere well, making the argument easy to follow. After cooling, the molecules in the solution began to cohere and form a solid.

Front: Fill in the blank: The negotiators grew frustrated with the company's ________ stance on the contract terms. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “unwilling to compromise”.
Back: intransigent intransigent (in-tran-suh-junt) adj. unwilling to compromise

Front: Define: intrepid (in-trep-id)
Back: adj. courageous The intrepid naturalist routinely braved storms and mudslides to document new species. Prefix: in- (meaning “not”), Root: trepid (from Latin trepidus, meaning “anxious” or “fearful”)

Front: Define: intrinsic (in-trin-zik)
Back: adj. related to an object's essence Unfortunately, some degree of inefficiency is intrinsic to all democracies. Prefix: intra- (meaning “within”), Root: secus (from Latin, meaning “following”)

Front: Define: inure (in-your)
Back: v. to become accustomed to something negative or unpleasant Nearby residents soon became inured to the noise from the construction project. Prefix: in- (meaning “in” or “into”), Root: ure (from Latin usus, meaning “use”)

Front: Define: invective (in-vek-tiv)
Back: adj. verbally abusive n. abusive or stern language What this debate needs is a little less invective and a little more substance. Prefix: in- (meaning “into”), Root: vehere (from Latin, meaning “to carry”)

Front: Define: irrevocable (ih-rev-ih-kuh-bull)
Back: adj. unable to be revoked; permanent The laws the king decreed were irrevocable even after he left the throne. Prefix: ir- (meaning “not”), Root: revocare (from Latin, meaning “to call back”), Suffix: -able (meaning “capable of”)

Front: Define: jocular (jock-yuh-lur)
Back: adj. related to jokes The boy was popular with his classmates due to his cheerful, jocular nature. Root: jocul (from Latin jocus, meaning “joke”), Suffix: -ar (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: kernel (kur-null)
Back: n. the central part of a situation or seed The kernel of the matter was that she didn't even know where to begin looking for a new house. Root: kern (from Old English cyrnel, meaning “seed” or “core”)

Front: Define: lackluster (lack-luss-tur)
Back: adj. not lively; not bright Tired from a long day, Susan gave a very lackluster performance during the dress rehearsal. Root: lack (meaning “absence”), Root: luster (from Latin lustrare, meaning “to illuminate”)

Front: Define: refractory (rih-frack-tuh-ree)
Back: adj. stubborn; difficult to treat or handle The doctors did not know how to deal with such a refractory infection. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: fract (from Latin frangere, meaning “to break”), Suffix: -ory (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: regiment (redj-ih-munt)
Back: n. a military unit of troops v. to enforce a strict order or conformity Four army regiments occupied the city last week. Root: regimen (from Latin, meaning “rule” or “system of order”)

Front: Define: remonstrate (rih-mon-strehyt)
Back: v. to protest Many special-interest groups remonstrated against the new legislation. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: monstrare (from Latin, meaning “to show”)

Front: Define: remunerate (rih-mew-nuh-rehyt)
Back: v. to compensate monetarily for trouble or work done Although they finally had to throw the computer out, Linda remunerated her friend for trying to fix it anyway. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: muner (from Latin munus, meaning “gift”), Suffix: -ate (forming verbs)

Front: Define: render (ren-der)
Back: v. to give, result in, or cause to become v. to do something for someone else His harsh words rendered her speechless. Root: rend (from Latin reddere, meaning “to give back”)

Front: Define: repose (rih-poze)
Back: n. peacefulness, rest v. to lie down or be stationary In the summer, she would often lie under the willow trees in complete repose. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: pose (from Latin pausare, meaning “to pause”)

Front: Define: repudiate (rih-pew-dee-ehyt)
Back: v. to renounce ownership or disown v. to refuse to recognize v. to reject as true The scientists who discovered the fossil were shocked when it was repudiated as a fake. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: pud (from Latin pudere, meaning “to be ashamed”), Suffix: -ate (forming verbs)

Front: Define: reticent (rett-ih-sunt)
Back: adj. not wanting to talk; reluctant When asked about the stolen vase, the maid was reticent even though she had seen the thief take it. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: ticere (from Latin, meaning “to be silent”)

Front: Define: retiring (rih-tie-ring)
Back: adj. shy; quiet During high school, Mary became so retiring that people sometimes didn't notice when they shared a class with her. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: tirer (from Old French, meaning “to draw”)

Front: Define: revere (rih-veer)
Back: v. to admire greatly; to honor The mayor was so revered by the village that every single man, woman, and child attended his funeral. Prefix: re- (meaning “again”), Root: vereri (from Latin, meaning “to respect”)

Front: Define: platitude (plat-ih-tewd)
Back: n. a cliché, dull, or unenlightening saying My father's favorite platitude was, “Winners never quit, quitters never win”. Root: plat (from French plat, meaning “flat”), Suffix: -itude (forming nouns indicating a state or condition)

Front: Define: pliant (ply-unt)
Back: adj. easy to change or bend adj. easy to convince The professor needed a particularly pliant mind for his brainwashing experiments. Root: pli (from Latin plicare, meaning “to fold”), Suffix: -ant (forming adjectives)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. courageous Hint: starts with “i”
Back: intrepid synonyms: brave, heroic, fearless, dauntless, adventurous The intrepid explorer ventured into the uncharted jungle without hesitation.

Front: Fill in the blank: The desire to learn is ________ to human nature. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “belonging naturally”.
Back: intrinsic intrinsic (in-trin-zik) adj. related to an object's essence

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to become accustomed to something negative or unpleasant Hint: starts with “i”
Back: inure synonyms: desensitize, familiarize, habituate, harden, acclimate, condition After years of working in harsh conditions, he became inured to the long hours and difficult tasks.

Front: Fill in the blank: The politician's speech was filled with ________ against his opponents. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “insulting or abusive language”.
Back: invective invective (in-vek-tiv) adj. verbally abusive n. abusive or stern language

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. unable to be revoked; permanent Hint: starts with “i”
Back: irrevocable synonyms: unchangeable, unalterable, final, binding, immutable The decision to sell the house was irrevocable once the contract was signed.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ personality always lightened the mood at gatherings. Hint: Starts with “j” and means “fond of joking”.
Back: jocular jocular (jock-yuh-lur) adj. related to jokes

Front: Name the vocab term: n. the central part of a situation or seed Hint: starts with “k”
Back: kernel synonyms: core, crux, essence, nucleus, heart At the kernel of the argument was a misunderstanding about expectations.

Front: Fill in the blank: The movie's ________ plot left the audience disappointed. Hint: Starts with “l” and means “dull or uninspired”.
Back: lackluster lackluster (lack-luss-tur) adj. not lively; not bright

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. stubborn; difficult to treat or handle Hint: starts with “r”
Back: refractory synonyms: resistant, immune, unresponsive, obstinate, headstrong, intractable The refractory patient refused to follow the doctor's advice.

Front: Fill in the blank: The new manager ________ the office, ensuring that everyone followed the rules to the letter. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “strictly organized or controlled”.
Back: regimented regiment (redj-ih-munt) n. a military unit of troops v. to enforce a strict order or conformity

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to protest Hint: starts with “r”
Back: remonstrate synonyms: argue, challenge, complain, dispute, object The workers remonstrated against the unfair treatment by organizing a strike.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was ________ handsomely for the extra hours he worked on the project. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “paid for work or service”.
Back: remunerated remunerate (rih-mew-nuh-rehyt) v. to compensate monetarily for trouble or work done

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to take forcibly, result in, or cause to become v. to do something for someone else Hint: starts with “r”
Back: render synonyms: cause, become, execute; carry out, accomplish, provide, deliver, perform The accident rendered him unable to continue his athletic career. She rendered assistance to the elderly man struggling with his groceries.

Front: Fill in the blank: After a long day of work, he sought ________ in the quiet of his garden. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “rest or relaxation”.
Back: repose repose (rih-poze) n. peacefulness n. rest

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to renounce ownership or disown v. to refuse to recognize v. to reject as true Hint: starts with “r”
Back: repudiate synonyms: reject, decline, disown, renounce, deny, abandon He repudiated his involvement in the scandal. The government repudiated the treaty after discovering the violation. She repudiated the claims made against her in court.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was ________ to share his opinions during the meeting. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “reserved or reluctant to speak”.
Back: reticent reticent (rett-ih-sunt) adj. not wanting to talk; reluctant

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. shy; quiet Hint: starts with “r”
Back: retiring synonyms: bashful, unassuming, reserved, modest, introverted Despite his retiring demeanor, he was well-liked by his colleagues.

Front: Fill in the blank: The community ________ its elders for their wisdom and experience. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “deeply respected”.
Back: revered revere (rih-veer) v. to admire greatly; to honor

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a cliché, dull, or unenlightening saying Hint: starts with “p”
Back: platitude synonyms: banality, cliché, triteness, overused expression, commonplace Her speech was full of empty platitudes that added nothing new to the discussion.

Front: Fill in the blank: He was so ________ that he often went along with whatever his friends suggested. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “easily bent or influenced”.
Back: pliant pliant (ply-unt) adj. easy to change or bend adj. easy to convince

Front: Define: poignant (poin-yunt)
Back: adj. so emotionally intense as to be painful Watching her daughter wake up was particularly poignant for her mother who had worried by her bedside the whole night. Root: poign (from Latin pungere, meaning “to prick” or “to pierce”)

Front: Define: polar (poe-lur)
Back: adj. related to opposite extremes or sides The two were so different their personalities could be considered polar opposites. Root: pol (from Greek polos, meaning “axis” or “pivot”)

Front: Define: polemic (puh-lem-ik)
Back: adj. relating to or involving critical or disputatious argument n. a controversial argument As soon as the graduate student obtained her doctorate, she published a polemic refutation of her mentor's work. Root: polem (from Greek polemos, meaning “war” or “struggle”)

Front: Define: ponderous (pon-dur-us)
Back: adj. difficult to handle due to heaviness adj. requiring a lot of work The ponderous task was completed in no time, thanks to the large number of volunteers we had. Root: ponder (from Latin pondus, meaning “weight”); Suffix: -ous (forming adjectives, meaning “full of”)

Front: Define: portend (pore-tend)
Back: v. to foretell The witch claimed that the stormy weather portended the ruler's downfall. Prefix: por- (variant of pro-, meaning “forward”); Root: tend (from Latin tendere, meaning “to stretch”)

Front: Define: posit (poz-it)
Back: v. to assume as fact Some physicists posit that the universe will expand forever. Root: posit (from Latin ponere, meaning “to place” or “to put”)

Front: Define: postulate (poss-chuh-lehyt)
Back: v. to assume a basic truth Economic theory postulates limits on essential resources as the basis of human behavior. Root: postul (from Latin postulare, meaning “to demand”); Suffix: -ate (forming verbs, meaning “to make” or “to act”)

Front: Define: bolster (bole-stur)
Back: v. to support The candidate's campaign was bolstered by endorsements by several former military leaders. Root: bolster (from Old English bolster, meaning “a long, thick pillow”)

Front: Define: bombastic (bom-bass-tick)
Back: adj. inflated, arrogant The bombastic way in which the author described his new novel repulsed me. Root: bombast (from Middle French bombace, meaning “cotton padding”); Suffix: -ic (forming adjectives, meaning “pertaining to”)

Front: Define: brood (brewd)
Back: n. a group of offspring v. to worry over The hen protected her new brood from the farmer's inspection. Root: brood (from Old English brōd, meaning “offspring”)

Front: Define: burgeon (burr-djun)
Back: v. to grow or develop rapidly and flourish The burgeoning mass of bees was heading straight for the picnic. Root: burgeon (from Old French borjoner, meaning “to bud”)

Front: Define: exacting (ig-zak-ting)
Back: adj. making severe demands or requirements adj. requiring great care The exacting professor wanted a 15-page paper due the next day in class. Prefix: ex- (meaning “out”); Root: act (from Latin agere, meaning “to do”); Suffix: -ing (forming adjectives, indicating an action or result)

Front: Define: rebuke (rih-byook)
Back: v. to reprimand, to scold sharply The child was rebuked for stealing candy. Prefix: re- (meaning “again” or “back”); Root: buke (from Old French buker, meaning “to strike”)

Front: Define: dulcet (duhl-sit)
Back: adj. pleasant sounding or looking The dulcet tone of the musical parody contrasted sharply with its offensive lyrics. Root: dulc (from Latin dulcis, meaning “sweet”)

Front: Define: toady (toh-dee)
Back: n. a flatterer, a yes man The president was surrounded by toadies rather than people with honest criticisms. Root: toad (from Middle English tode, meaning “toad”); Suffix: -y (forming nouns, indicating a characteristic)

Front: Define: gall (gawl)
Back: n. audacity, impudence He had the gall to request a raise after it was discovered that he was calling in sick in order to play golf. Root: gall (from Old English gealla, meaning “bile”)

Front: Define: cloying (kloi-ing)
Back: adj. unpleasant due to excess; sickeningly sweet or sentimental Unfortunately, cloying romantic comedies are sure box-office hits, and so Hollywood continues to churn them out. Root: cloy (from Middle English cloyen, meaning “to hinder”); Suffix: -ing (forming adjectives, indicating an action or result)

Front: Define: sully (suhl-ee)
Back: v. to stain or tarnish the purity of Joe's reputation as an ethical CEO was sullied by his selfish actions during his company's merger. Root: sul (from Old French souillier, meaning “to soil”); Suffix: -y (forming verbs, indicating an action)

Front: Define: defile (dih-fahyl)
Back: v. to dirty, spoil, or dishonor v. to violate the chastity of The holy site was unwittingly defiled when the invaders, for whom it held no special meaning, used it as a stable. Prefix: de- (meaning “down” or “away”); Root: file (from Old French fil, meaning “thread”)

Front: Define: pithy (pith-ee)
Back: adj. concise and relevant Satya's pithy keynote speech was more enlightening than the endless lectures that had preceded it. Root: pith (from Old English piþa, meaning “essential part”); Suffix: -y (forming adjectives, indicating a characteristic)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. so emotionally intense as to be painful Hint: starts with “p”
Back: poignant synonyms: agonizing, bitter; sharp, keen, touching, moving, heartrending The movie's poignant ending left many in the audience in tears.

Front: Fill in the blank: Their political views were ________, making compromise difficult. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “opposite in nature”.
Back: polar polar (poe-lur) adj. related to opposite extremes or sides

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. controversial n. a controversial argument Hint: starts with “p”
Back: polemic synonyms: refutation, dispute, debate, controversy, argument The author's polemic essay sparked a heated debate. He engaged in a polemic with the journalist over the ethics of the new policy.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ box required two people to move it. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “heavy or clumsy”.
Back: ponderous ponderous (pon-dur-us) adj. difficult to handle due to heaviness; or adj. requiring a lot of work

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to foretell Hint: starts with “p”
Back: portend synonyms: foreshadow, harbinger, signal, indicate, presage Dark clouds portend an approaching storm.

Front: Fill in the blank: The scientist ________ a theory based on the available evidence. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “assumed or suggested”.
Back: posited posit (poz-it) v. to assume as fact

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to assume a basic truth Hint: starts with “p”
Back: postulate synonyms: assert, premise, suppose, hypothesize, posit, claim The philosopher postulated that human beings are inherently good.

Front: Fill in the blank: The new evidence helped ________ his argument in court. Hint: Starts with “b” and means “to support or strengthen”.
Back: bolster bolster (bole-stur) v. to support

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. inflated, arrogant Hint: starts with “b”
Back: bombastic synonyms: grandiose, egotistical, pompous, verbose, pretentious His bombastic speech was filled with grandiose claims that lacked substance.

Front: Fill in the blank: The mother hen carefully watched over her ________ of chicks. Hint: Starts with “b” and means “to dwell gloomily on something”.
Back: brood brood (brewd) n. a group of offspring v. to worry over

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to grow Hint: starts with “b”
Back: burgeon synonyms: blossom, grow, expand, flourish, thrive, multiply Her business began to burgeon after she introduced a new product line.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ standards made it difficult to meet her expectations. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “demanding great effort or precision”.
Back: exacting exacting (ig-zak-ting) adj. making severe demands or requirements adj. requiring great care

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to reprimand, to scold sharply Hint: starts with “r”
Back: rebuke synonyms: berate, blame, condemn, scold, reprimand, admonish The teacher rebuked the student for not completing his homework on time.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ tones of the violin soothed everyone in the room. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “sweet and soothing”.
Back: dulcet dulcet (duhl-sit) adj. pleasant sounding or looking

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a flatterer, a yes man Hint: starts with “t”
Back: toady synonyms: doter, brownnoser, sycophant, flatterer, fawning He surrounded himself with toadies who never questioned his decisions.

Front: Fill in the blank: It took a lot of ________ for him to make such bold demands after his recent mistakes. Hint: Starts with “g” and means “bold rudeness”.
Back: gall gall (gawl) n. audacity, impudence

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. unpleasant due to excess; sickeningly sweet or sentimental Hint: starts with “c”
Back: cloying synonyms: cheesy, overly sentimental, sappy, sickly, sweet, excessive The movie's cloying romance scenes made it difficult to take the story seriously.

Front: Fill in the blank: The scandal ________ his once pristine reputation. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “damaged purity or integrity”.
Back: sullied sully (suhl-ee) v. to stain or tarnish the purity of

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to dirty, spoil, dishonor v. to violate the chastity of Hint: starts with “d”
Back: defile synonyms: befoul, besmirch, corrupt, desecrate, degrade The vandals defiled the historic monument with graffiti. The ancient tale spoke of a king who sought to defile the queen, only to be punished by the gods.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ remarks during the meeting were both insightful and brief. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “concise and forcefully expressive”.
Back: pithy pithy (pith-ee) adj. concise and relevant

Front: Define: slovenly (sluhv-uhn-lee)
Back: adj. untidy, disheveled; unclean in appearance or habits The other dinner guests held the slovenly drunkard in contempt. Root: sloven (from Middle English slovein, meaning “careless person”)

Front: Define: onerous (oh-ner-uhs)
Back: adj. causing hardship; burdensome, troublesome The students relished making the teacher's job as onerous as possible. Root: oner (from Latin onus, meaning “burden”)

Front: Define: scourge (skurdj)
Back: n. a plague or cause of affliction n. something that causes suffering The scourge of drugs in American society will be its downfall. Root: scourge (from Latin corrigia, meaning “thong, whip”)

Front: Define: candor (kan-der)
Back: n. the quality of being frank, sincere, or impartial in expression Giorgio was known for his candor, so it surprised no one when he began to talk at length about his love life. Root: cand (from Latin candere, meaning “to shine, to be white”)

Front: Define: boor (boor)
Back: n. a crude, unmannered, or rude person The boor upset everyone at the fancy restaurant. Root: boor (from Dutch boer, meaning “farmer”)

Front: Define: moribund (mawr-uh-buhnd)
Back: adj. dying, decaying, on the brink of extinction The moribund customs of the indigenous culture are only practiced in a few outlying areas. Root: mori (from Latin mori, meaning “to die”)

Front: Define: pine (pahyn)
Back: v. to suffer from extreme desire or painful longing; to yearn deeply v. to waste away with grief The sailor's wife pined for him all through the long, harsh winter. Root: pine (from Old English pinian, meaning “to cause to suffer”)

Front: Define: siren (sahy-ruhn)
Back: n. a beautiful, seductive, or charming woman The young men of the neighborhood are smitten with the siren who moved in last week. Root: siren (from Greek Seirēn, a mythological creature)

Front: Define: cache (kash)
Back: n. a hidden place, a secret storage n. a place for valuables The bomb shelter had a cache of resources capable of supporting the family. Root: cache (from French cacher, meaning “to hide”)

Front: Define: lionize (lahy-uh-nahyz)
Back: v. to treat a person as a celebrity When the musical sensation returned to her hometown, she was lionized by everyone she knew. Suffix: -ize (a verb-forming suffix meaning “to make or to treat as”)

Front: Define: skulk (skuhlk)
Back: v. to lie in wait; to hide with evil intent The fugitive was spotted skulking about the docks just past midnight. Root: skulk (from Old Norse skulke, meaning “to lurk”)

Front: Define: emendation (ee-muhn-dey-shuhn)
Back: n. a correction or revision in a text Once the emendations have been made, the pamphlet can be sent to the printer. Root: mend (from Latin emendare, meaning “to correct”)

Front: Define: euphony (yoo-fuh-nee)
Back: n. a pleasant, harmonious sound The euphony of the Italian language is unparalleled. Prefix: eu- (from Greek, meaning “good, well”); Root: phon (from Greek phone, meaning “sound”)

Front: Define: terse (turs)
Back: adj. succinct, curt Your terse apology does not even begin to give an adequate explanation for your behavior. Root: ters (from Latin tersus, meaning “wiped off, clean”)

Front: Define: trite (trahyt)
Back: adj. uninteresting due to overuse; hackneyed Though some may find Valentine's Day chocolates trite, I look forward to every box I get. Root: trit (from Latin tritus, meaning “worn, rubbed”)

Front: Define: malefactor (mal-uh-fak-ter)
Back: n. evildoer, culprit, a violator of the law The Nuremberg trials brought the Nazi malefactors to justice. Prefix: male- (from Latin malus, meaning “bad”); Root: fact (from Latin facere, meaning “to do”)

Front: Define: obtuse (uhb-toos)
Back: adj. stupid, dull adj. slow to perceive, feel, or respond The obtuse response lacked a great deal of sophistication. Root: tuse (from Latin obtusus, meaning “blunt”)

Front: Define: ingratiate (ing-grey-shee-eyt)
Back: v. to work oneself into the favor of someone The intern ingratiated himself to his superiors starting on the first day. Prefix: in- (meaning “into”); Root: grati (from Latin gratia, meaning “favor”)

Front: Define: travesty (trav-uh-stee)
Back: n. a perverse or ludicrous representation Thom's checkered tux was a travesty of good taste. Root: vest (from Latin vestire, meaning “to clothe”)

Front: Define: philology (fih-lol-uh-djee)
Back: n. the study of linguistics and literature The students of philology were hunched over their Spanish literature texts. Root: phil (from Greek philos, meaning “loving”); Root: logy (from Greek logos, meaning “word, reason”)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. untidy, disheveled; unclean in appearance or habits Hint: starts with “s”
Back: slovenly synonyms: dirty, careless, messy, unkempt, disorganized His slovenly appearance made a poor impression during the job interview.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ task of filing taxes each year often leaves people feeling frustrated. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “burdensome or difficult”.
Back: onerous onerous (oh-ner-uhs) adj. causing hardship; burdensome, troublesome

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a plague or cause of affliction Hint: starts with “s”
Back: scourge synonyms: torment, affliction, pestilence, curse, bane, blight The disease was a scourge on the population, causing widespread suffering.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ in addressing the issues at hand earned her the respect of her colleagues. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “honesty and openness”.
Back: candor candor (kan-der) n. the quality of being frank, sincere, or impartial in expression

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a crude, unmannered, or rude person Hint: starts with “b”
Back: boor synonyms: goon, oaf, barbarian, lout, clod, ruffian The boor at the party offended everyone with his rude jokes and behavior.

Front: Fill in the blank: The once-thriving industry is now ________, with very few companies still operating. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “at the point of death”.
Back: moribund moribund (mawr-uh-buhnd) adj. dying, decaying, on the brink of extinction

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to suffer from extreme desire or painful longing v. to waste away with grief Hint: starts with “p”
Back: pine synonyms: dream, hanker, lust, long, yearn, ache He spent months pining for his lost love. She pined away after the death of her beloved pet.

Front: Fill in the blank: The actress played the role of a ________, luring men to their doom with her beauty. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “a tempting but dangerous lure”.
Back: siren siren (sahy-ruhn) n. a beautiful, seductive, and charming woman

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a hidden place, a secret storage n. a place for valuables Hint: starts with “c”
Back: cache synonyms: secret storage place, hoard, stash, reserve They found a cache of old coins hidden in the attic.

Front: Fill in the blank: The young athlete was ________ by the media after his impressive victory. Hint: Starts with “l” and means “treated as a celebrity”.
Back: lionized lionize (lahy-uh-nahyz) v. to treat a person as a celebrity

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to lie, to sneak into hiding, with evil intent Hint: starts with “s”
Back: skulk synonyms: tiptoe, sneak, slither, creep, lurk, hide, prowl He skulked in the shadows, waiting for the right moment to strike.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ made to the manuscript improved its clarity. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “a correction or revision”.
Back: emendation emendation (ee-muhn-dey-shuhn) n. a correction or revisions in a text

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a pleasant, harmonious sound Hint: starts with “e”
Back: euphony synonyms: melody, symphony, harmony, music, tune The euphony of the orchestra's performance captivated the audience.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ reply made it clear he was not interested in continuing the conversation. Hint: Starts with “t” and means “brief and to the point”.
Back: terse terse (turs) adj. succinct, curt

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. uninteresting due to overuse; hackneyed Hint: starts with “t”
Back: trite synonyms: banal, common, stale, cliché, overused The movie's trite dialogue made it predictable and boring.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ was finally caught after years of evading the authorities. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “a wrongdoer or criminal”.
Back: malefactor malefactor (mal-uh-fak-ter) n. evildoer, culprit, a violator of the law

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. stupid, dull adj. slow to perceive, feel, or respond Hint: starts with “o”
Back: obtuse synonyms: dense, dumb, insensitive, ignorant, thick-headed, slow-witted He was so obtuse that he didn't realize he had offended her with his comment.

Front: Fill in the blank: She tried to ________ herself with the boss by always complimenting his ideas. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “to gain favor through flattery”.
Back: ingratiate ingratiate (ing-grey-shee-eyt) v. to work oneself into the favor of someone

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a perverse or ludicrous parody or exaggeration Hint: starts with “t”
Back: travesty synonyms: caricature, burlesque, parody, satire, farce The film was a travesty of the original story, distorting its meaning entirely.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her passion for ________ led her to study ancient texts and their languages. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “the study of language”.
Back: philology philology (fih-lol-uh-djee) n. the study of linguistics and literature
